title: 105_hr4379
content: The "Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998" allows for a credit to reimburse employers and employees for a portion of their Social Security taxes. The "Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998" provides a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year equal to a percentage of the taxpayer's social security taxes if there is a Federal budget surplus of over $1,000,000,000 in the fiscal year. This credit does not apply until the Social Security trust funds are solvent. The Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998 allows for a credit against the tax imposed for the taxable year based on the taxpayer's social security taxes. The applicable percentage is determined by the Trustees of the Federal Old Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The base percentage applies to social security taxes up to $3,000, while the phasedown percentage applies to amounts exceeding $3,000. The Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998 provides a reduction in Treasury revenues equal to 33\1/3\ percent of the Federal budget surplus for the most recent fiscal year. The phasedown percentage is calculated based on the excess of a taxpayer's social security taxes over $3,000 compared to the maximum social security taxes over $3,000. The Budget Surplus Dividend Act of 1998 reduces Treasury revenues by 33\1/3\ percent of the Federal budget surplus. The phasedown percentage is determined by comparing a taxpayer's social security taxes over $3,000 to the maximum social security taxes. Special rules apply for dollar limitations and self-employed individuals. The term 'social security taxes' includes taxes on employees, employers, self-employment income, and specific taxes on individuals. The term 'social security taxes' includes taxes on employees, employers, self-employment income, and specific taxes on individuals. Coordination with special refund of social security taxes is excluded. Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates are treated as taxes. The item relating to section 35 in part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by striking and replacing it. SEC. 3. Appropriation of 33\1/3\ percent of federal budget surplus to reduce public debt. An amount equal to 33\1/3\ percent of the surplus will be used to pay off government obligations. Obligations paid with these funds will be canceled and retired. SEC. 4. Use 33\1/3\ percent of federal budget surplus to increase nondefense discretionary spending limits. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will increase discretionary spending limits for new budget authority by 33\1/3\ percent of any Federal budget surplus in the following fiscal year. This adjustment will be made on a pro rata basis between nondefense categories. Effective date depends on the solvency of Social Security Trust Funds. The Act and its amendments will come into effect when the Social Security Trust Funds are deemed to be in close actuarial balance through 2070 by the Board of Trustees. This determination will be included in the first annual report after it is made.
